At the Machine Room Air Unit, liquid ammonia flowing through the coil is partially boiled as it absorbs heat from the air in the Machine Room. The partially vaporized ammonia (liquid/vapor mixture) is returned to the High Temp LPR.

The high temperature recirculated liquid from the High Temp LPR experiences a pressure drop as it flows through the motorized valve or the hand expansion valve prior to entering the Low Temp LPR. The Low Temp LPR then pumps low temperature recirculated liquid to five evaporator coils within the FPS Freezer.  

The FPS Freezer consists of a pre-cool coil and five freezer coils. The precool coil receives high temp recirculated liquid from the High Temp LPR, while the five freezer coils receive low temp recirculated liquid from the Low Temp LPR. The liquid within the coils partially vaporizers as it absorbs heat from the product (potatoes or blueberries) passing through the unit. The wet suction (liquid/vapor mixture) from the precool coil returns to the High Temp LPR, while the wet suction from the freezer coils returns to the Low Temp LPR. 

Freezer coils #1-4 within the FPS Freezer also receive hot gas from the compressors for coil defrost. Coil defrost is sequential (one coil at a time) and occurs based on programming within the control panel for the FPS Freezer. Defrost of freezer coil #5 occurs when the FPS Freezer is shut down for cleaning. Defrost for the pre-cool coil is not necessary (frost/ice accumulation on the coil is not expected as the coil operates at a higher pressure/temperature).

The pressure/temperature of the High Temp LPR and Low Temp LPR is maintained by the compressors, which draw suction from the vessels. Compressor SC-1 draws high stage suction from the High Temp LPR whereas Compressors SC-2 to SC-4 draw low stage suction from the Low Temp LPR and economizer suction from the High Temp LPR. Five Year Accident History
According to the EPA RMP regulation, the five year accident history covers only certain releases:
•	The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.  
•	The release must have caused at least one of the following:
o	On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or
o	Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

The system is of new construction and is estimated to start up in mid-September 2023; therefore, there have been no releases that meet the above criteria.

Emergency Response Program
Trinity Frozen Foods has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) addressing ammonia releases and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure. Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP and trained in the evacuation procedure.  In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the trained personnel will investigate the issue and contact the fire department for assistance as needed.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
A Process Hazard Analysis was performed on the ammonia refrigeration system, and the evaluation resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of developing new procedures, providing employee trai

Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies
Trinity Frozen Foods is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities. This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only trained operators are permitted to perform system operations.  Trinity Frozen Foods has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition. All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
Trinity Frozen Foods is located at 6064 Deep Branch Road in Pembroke, North Carolina.  Ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the facility’s refrigeration system.  The system is used to freeze food products (potatoes and blueberries).  The system uses a maximum of 13,000 pounds of ammonia. A description of how the refrigeration system operates is as follows.

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the evaporative condensers to the High Pressure Receiver. The High Pressure Receiver feeds high pressure liquid ammonia to the compressors SC-1 – SC-4 as liquid injection for oil cooling purposes. Liquid in the High Pressure Receiver is also fed to the High Temperature Low Pressure Recirculator (High Temp LPR).  

Prior to entering the High Temp LPR, the high pressure liquid experiences a pressure drop as it flows through the motorized valve or the hand expansion valve of the liquid feed assembly.
